item.title: Example Page 1
item.description:

item.title: Example Talk
item.description:
Click on the Slides button above to view the built-in slides feature.

Slides can be added in a few ways:

  • Create slides using Academic’s Slides feature and link using slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Upload an existing slide deck to static/ and link using url_slides parameter in the front matter of the talk file
  • Embed your slides (e.g. Google Slides) or presentation video on this page using shortcodes.

Further talk details can easily be added to this page using Markdown and $\rm \LaTeX$ math code.

item.title: COVID-19 Situation in Iran
item.description:
Background

Iran is one of if not the worse-hit country in the world from the covid-19 pandemic. It was the first country in Middle East to come into contact with the virus when it officially announced with 2 deaths from the virus on 19 February 2020.

This pandemic could not arrive at a worse time. It coincided with country’s parliamentary election and also 1979 Islamic revolution- its reputation was (and still is) at stake.

Furthermore, their economy was in turmoil even before the outbreak, as tough sanctions progressively tightened as part of Trump’s administration’s “maximum pressure strategy” after US withdrew from international nuclear agreement with Iran. This drastically drained Iran’s ability to access medical and healthcare supplies to combat the virus, urging Iran appeal for a $5 billion emergency loan from International Monetary Fund(IMF). This also implicated its testing capabilities and inadequate testing kits; having only few labs to obtain test results, it delayed testing extensively.

All these amid rising political tensions nationally and internationally. In November 2019, the oil-rich country faced an unprecedented oil price hike and widespread protests were ravaging the country. While the demand for oil decreases. In January 2020, Iran had to deal with US assassination of top Iranian general and mistake of firing missle at Ukrainian airliner.

These are sensitive and crucial times for the government. Tough decisions needs to made as Iran faces the pandemic in the busiest period of the year (Iranian New Year). As Iran soon become the epicenter of the virus, many criticisms arise that the government incentivized for not being transparent in updating the local situation to the locals and rest of the world amid data leak. Iran had started off with the highest mortality rate outside China.

With lifting of restrictions lurking in the talks, I think it is reasonable to doubt if it is premature as the economy cannot sustain any longer or the government is playing down the situation. We might better understand how the virus unfolded given some data.

Data Description

Data serves to facilitate data exploration into Iran’s critical situation motivated by lack of studies conducted.

Virus containment & measures

These 2 tables are looks at the related to the effect of the virus but also the government measures implemented to combat the virus. The data sources comes from John Hopkins University CSSE and Assessmenet Capacities Project (ACAPS) respectively. These are smoothly accessible via tidycovid19 package.

Economic outlook

For economic outlook, variables were centered around the six key indicators of economy according from IMF.
alfred package was used extensively to extract the data.

Data across past 10 years were used. Last Data vantage chosen (4 April 2020). Note than year 2021 is an estimate by IMF.

Variables include:

Variable Description
year Year of measurement
real_gdp Real GDP in Constant Price, not seasonally adjusted (in %)
non_oil_real_gdp portion of GDP contributed by non-oil sectors
oil_real_gdp portion of GDP contributed by oil sectors
CPI inflation rate calculated via CPI
unemployment_rate unemployment rate
current_ac_balance current account balance to analyse net exports
net_lending_borrowing Central government net lending/borrowing(central government fiscal balance)

item.title: An example preprint / working paper
item.description:
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.

item.title: Slides
item.description:
Create slides in Markdown with Academic

Academic | Documentation

Features

  • Efficiently write slides in Markdown
  • 3-in-1: Create, Present, and Publish your slides
  • Supports speaker notes
  • Mobile friendly slides

Controls

  • Next: Right Arrow or Space
  • Previous: Left Arrow
  • Start: Home
  • Finish: End
  • Overview: Esc
  • Speaker notes: S
  • Fullscreen: F
  • Zoom: Alt + Click
  • PDF Export: E

Code Highlighting

Inline code: variable

Code block:

porridge = "blueberry"
if porridge == "blueberry":
    print("Eating...")

Math

In-line math: $x + y = z$

Block math:

$$ f\left( x \right) = ;\frac{{2\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x - 4} \right)}}{{\left( {x + 4} \right)\left( {x + 1} \right)}} $$

Fragments

Make content appear incrementally

{{% fragment %}} One {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} **Two** {{% /fragment %}}
{{% fragment %}} Three {{% /fragment %}}

Press Space to play!

One Two Three

A fragment can accept two optional parameters:

  • class: use a custom style (requires definition in custom CSS)
  • weight: sets the order in which a fragment appears

Speaker Notes

Add speaker notes to your presentation

{{% speaker_note %}}
- Only the speaker can read these notes
- Press `S` key to view
{{% /speaker_note %}}

Press the S key to view the speaker notes!

  • Only the speaker can read these notes
  • Press S key to view

Themes

  • black: Black background, white text, blue links (default)
  • white: White background, black text, blue links
  • league: Gray background, white text, blue links
  • beige: Beige background, dark text, brown links
  • sky: Blue background, thin dark text, blue links
  • night: Black background, thick white text, orange links
  • serif: Cappuccino background, gray text, brown links
  • simple: White background, black text, blue links
  • solarized: Cream-colored background, dark green text, blue links

Custom Slide

Customize the slide style and background

{{< slide background-image="/media/boards.jpg" >}}
{{< slide background-color="#0000FF" >}}
{{< slide class="my-style" >}}

Custom CSS Example

Let’s make headers navy colored.

Create assets/css/reveal_custom.css with:

.reveal section h1,
.reveal section h2,
.reveal section h3 {
  color: navy;
}

Questions?

Ask

Documentation

item.title: An example journal article

Click the Cite button above to demo the feature to enable visitors to import publication metadata into their reference management software.
Click the Slides button above to demo Academic’s Markdown slides feature.

Supplementary notes can be added here, including code and math.
